trans-unit.source: Use the autoscaling application block (.NET) | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Use the autoscaling application block (.NET) | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use the Autoscaling Application for Azure. Code samples are written in C# and use the .NET API.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use the Autoscaling Application for Azure. Code samples are written in C# and use the .NET API.

trans-unit.source: This guide will demonstrate how to perform common scenarios using the Autoscaling Application Block from the <linkText>Microsoft Enterprise Library 5.0 Integration Pack for Azure</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: This guide will demonstrate how to perform common scenarios using the Autoscaling Application Block from the <linkText>Microsoft Enterprise Library 5.0 Integration Pack for Azure</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The samples are written in C\# and use the .NET API.
trans-unit.target: The samples are written in C\# and use the .NET API.

trans-unit.source: The scenarios covered include hosting the block, using constraint rules, and using reactive rules.
trans-unit.target: The scenarios covered include hosting the block, using constraint rules, and using reactive rules.

trans-unit.source: For more information on the Autoscaling Application Block, see the <linkText>Next Steps</linkText><title></title> section.
trans-unit.target: For more information on the Autoscaling Application Block, see the <linkText>Next Steps</linkText><title></title> section.

trans-unit.source: The Autoscaling Application Block can automatically scale your Azure application based on rules that you define specifically for your application.
trans-unit.target: The Autoscaling Application Block can automatically scale your Azure application based on rules that you define specifically for your application.

trans-unit.source: You can use these rules to help your Azure application maintain its throughput in response to changes in its workload, while at the same time control the costs associated with hosting your application in Azure.
trans-unit.target: You can use these rules to help your Azure application maintain its throughput in response to changes in its workload, while at the same time control the costs associated with hosting your application in Azure.

trans-unit.source: Along with scaling by increasing or decreasing the number of role instances in your application, the block also enables you to use other scaling actions such as throttling certain functionality within your application or using custom-defined actions.
trans-unit.target: Along with scaling by increasing or decreasing the number of role instances in your application, the block also enables you to use other scaling actions such as throttling certain functionality within your application or using custom-defined actions.

trans-unit.source: You can choose to host the block in an Azure role or in an on-premises application.
trans-unit.target: You can choose to host the block in an Azure role or in an on-premises application.

trans-unit.source: The Autoscaling Application Block is part of the <linkText>Microsoft Enterprise Library 5.0 Integration Pack for Azure</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: The Autoscaling Application Block is part of the <linkText>Microsoft Enterprise Library 5.0 Integration Pack for Azure</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: In the following diagram, the green line shows a plot of the number of running instances of an Azure role over two days.
trans-unit.target: In the following diagram, the green line shows a plot of the number of running instances of an Azure role over two days.

trans-unit.source: The number of instances changes automatically over time in response to a set of autoscaling rules.
trans-unit.target: The number of instances changes automatically over time in response to a set of autoscaling rules.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>diagram of sample autoscaling</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>diagram of sample autoscaling</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The block uses two types of rules to define the autoscaling behavior for your application:
trans-unit.target: The block uses two types of rules to define the autoscaling behavior for your application:

trans-unit.source: Constraint Rules: To set upper and lower bounds on the number of instances, for example, let's say that between 8:00 and 10:00 every morning you want a minimum of four and a maximum of six instances, then you use a constraint rule.
trans-unit.target: Constraint Rules: To set upper and lower bounds on the number of instances, for example, let's say that between 8:00 and 10:00 every morning you want a minimum of four and a maximum of six instances, then you use a constraint rule.

trans-unit.source: In the diagram, the red and blue lines represent constraint rules.
trans-unit.target: In the diagram, the red and blue lines represent constraint rules.

trans-unit.source: For example, at point A in the diagram, the minimum number of role instances rises from two to four, in order to accommodate the anticipated increase in the application's workload at this time.
trans-unit.target: For example, at point A in the diagram, the minimum number of role instances rises from two to four, in order to accommodate the anticipated increase in the application's workload at this time.

trans-unit.source: At point B in the diagram, the number of role instances is prevented from climbing above five in order to control the running costs of the application.
trans-unit.target: At point B in the diagram, the number of role instances is prevented from climbing above five in order to control the running costs of the application.

trans-unit.source: Reactive Rules: To enable the number of role instances to change in response to unpredictable changes in demand, you use reactive rules.
trans-unit.target: Reactive Rules: To enable the number of role instances to change in response to unpredictable changes in demand, you use reactive rules.

trans-unit.source: At point C in the diagram, the block automatically reduces the number of role instances, from four to three, in response to a reduction in workload.
trans-unit.target: At point C in the diagram, the block automatically reduces the number of role instances, from four to three, in response to a reduction in workload.

trans-unit.source: At point D, the block detects an increase in workload and automatically increases the number of running role instances from three to four.
trans-unit.target: At point D, the block detects an increase in workload and automatically increases the number of running role instances from three to four.

trans-unit.source: The block stores its configuration settings in two stores:
trans-unit.target: The block stores its configuration settings in two stores:

trans-unit.source: Rules Store: The Rules Store holds your business configuration; a list of all the autoscaling rules that you have defined for your Azure application.
trans-unit.target: Rules Store: The Rules Store holds your business configuration; a list of all the autoscaling rules that you have defined for your Azure application.

trans-unit.source: This store is typically an XML file that is located where the Autoscaling Application Block can read it, for example in Azure blob storage or in a local file.
trans-unit.target: This store is typically an XML file that is located where the Autoscaling Application Block can read it, for example in Azure blob storage or in a local file.

trans-unit.source: Service Information Store: The Service Information Store stores your operational configuration, which is the service model of your Azure application.
trans-unit.target: Service Information Store: The Service Information Store stores your operational configuration, which is the service model of your Azure application.

trans-unit.source: This service model includes all of the information about your Azure application (such as role names and storage account details) that the block needs to be able to collect data points from the target Azure application and to perform scaling operations.
trans-unit.target: This service model includes all of the information about your Azure application (such as role names and storage account details) that the block needs to be able to collect data points from the target Azure application and to perform scaling operations.

trans-unit.source: Reactive rules can use performance counter data from roles as part of the rule definition.
trans-unit.target: Reactive rules can use performance counter data from roles as part of the rule definition.

trans-unit.source: For example, a reactive rule may monitor the CPU utilization of an Azure role to determine whether the block should initiate a scaling operation.
trans-unit.target: For example, a reactive rule may monitor the CPU utilization of an Azure role to determine whether the block should initiate a scaling operation.

trans-unit.source: The block reads performance counter data from the Azure Diagnostics table named WADPerformanceCountersTable in Azure storage.
trans-unit.target: The block reads performance counter data from the Azure Diagnostics table named WADPerformanceCountersTable in Azure storage.

trans-unit.source: By default, Azure does not write performance counter data to the Azure Diagnostics table in Azure storage.
trans-unit.target: By default, Azure does not write performance counter data to the Azure Diagnostics table in Azure storage.

trans-unit.source: Therefore, you should modify the roles from which you need to collect performance counter data to save this data.
trans-unit.target: Therefore, you should modify the roles from which you need to collect performance counter data to save this data.

trans-unit.source: For details about how to enable performance counters in your application, see <linkText>Using performance counters in Azure</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For details about how to enable performance counters in your application, see <linkText>Using performance counters in Azure</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: You can host the Autoscaling Application Block either in an Azure role or in an on-premises application.
trans-unit.target: You can host the Autoscaling Application Block either in an Azure role or in an on-premises application.

trans-unit.source: The Autoscaling Application Block is typically hosted in a separate application from the target application that you want to scale automatically.
trans-unit.target: The Autoscaling Application Block is typically hosted in a separate application from the target application that you want to scale automatically.

trans-unit.source: This section provides guidelines about how to configure your host application.
trans-unit.target: This section provides guidelines about how to configure your host application.

trans-unit.source: Before you can use the Autoscaling Application Block in your Visual Studio project, you will need to obtain the Autoscaling Application Block binaries and add references to them in your project.
trans-unit.target: Before you can use the Autoscaling Application Block in your Visual Studio project, you will need to obtain the Autoscaling Application Block binaries and add references to them in your project.

trans-unit.source: The NuGet Visual Studio extension makes it easy to install and update libraries and tools in Visual Studio and Visual Web Developer.
trans-unit.target: The NuGet Visual Studio extension makes it easy to install and update libraries and tools in Visual Studio and Visual Web Developer.

trans-unit.source: The Autoscaling Application Block NuGet package is the easiest way to get the Autscaling Application Block APIs.
trans-unit.target: The Autoscaling Application Block NuGet package is the easiest way to get the Autscaling Application Block APIs.

trans-unit.source: For more information about NuGet, and how to install and use the NuGet Visual Studio extension, see the NuGet website.
trans-unit.target: For more information about NuGet, and how to install and use the NuGet Visual Studio extension, see the NuGet website.

trans-unit.source: Once you have the NuGet Package Manager installed, to install the Autoscaling NuGet package in your application, do the following:
trans-unit.target: Once you have the NuGet Package Manager installed, to install the Autoscaling NuGet package in your application, do the following:

trans-unit.source: Open the NuGet Package Manager Console window.
trans-unit.target: Open the NuGet Package Manager Console window.

trans-unit.source: In the Tools menu, select Library Package Manager, the select Package Manager Console.
trans-unit.target: In the Tools menu, select Library Package Manager, the select Package Manager Console.

trans-unit.source: Enter the following command in the NuGet Package Manager Console window:
trans-unit.target: Enter the following command in the NuGet Package Manager Console window:

trans-unit.source: Installing the NuGet package updates your project with all the necessary assemblies and references that you need to use the Autoscaling Application Block.
trans-unit.target: Installing the NuGet package updates your project with all the necessary assemblies and references that you need to use the Autoscaling Application Block.

trans-unit.source: Your project now includes the XML schema files for the autoscaling rule definitions and autoscaling service information.
trans-unit.target: Your project now includes the XML schema files for the autoscaling rule definitions and autoscaling service information.

trans-unit.source: The project now also includes a readme file that contains important information about the Autoscaling Application Block:
trans-unit.target: The project now also includes a readme file that contains important information about the Autoscaling Application Block:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>files configured by autoscaling NuGet package</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>files configured by autoscaling NuGet package</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Your project must target the .NET Framework 4.
trans-unit.target: Your project must target the .NET Framework 4.

trans-unit.source: To change or verify the target framework:
trans-unit.target: To change or verify the target framework:

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click on the project name and select Properties.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click on the project name and select Properties.

trans-unit.source: In the Application tab of the Properties window, make sure Target framework is set to .NET Framework 4.
trans-unit.target: In the Application tab of the Properties window, make sure Target framework is set to .NET Framework 4.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>image</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>image</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Add the following code namespace declarations to the top of any C\# file in which you wish to programmatically access the Autoscaling Application Block:
trans-unit.target: Add the following code namespace declarations to the top of any C\# file in which you wish to programmatically access the Autoscaling Application Block:

trans-unit.source: Use the IServiceLocator.GetInstance method to instantiate the Autoscaler, and then call the Autoscaler.Start method to run the Autoscaler.
trans-unit.target: Use the IServiceLocator.GetInstance method to instantiate the Autoscaler, and then call the Autoscaler.Start method to run the Autoscaler.

trans-unit.source: Typically, you store your service model (a description of your Azure environment that includes information about subscriptions, hosted services, roles, and storages accounts) in an XML file.
trans-unit.target: Typically, you store your service model (a description of your Azure environment that includes information about subscriptions, hosted services, roles, and storages accounts) in an XML file.

trans-unit.source: You can find a copy of the schema for this XML file in the AutoscalingServiceModel.xsd file in your project.
trans-unit.target: You can find a copy of the schema for this XML file in the AutoscalingServiceModel.xsd file in your project.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, this schema provides Intellisense and validation when you edit the service model XML file.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, this schema provides Intellisense and validation when you edit the service model XML file.

trans-unit.source: Create a new XML file called services.xml in your project.
trans-unit.target: Create a new XML file called services.xml in your project.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, you must ensure that the service model file is copied to the output folder.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, you must ensure that the service model file is copied to the output folder.

trans-unit.source: To do this:
trans-unit.target: To do this:

trans-unit.source: Right-click on the file and select Properties.
trans-unit.target: Right-click on the file and select Properties.

trans-unit.source: Within the Properties pane, set the Copy to Output Directory value to Copy always.
trans-unit.target: Within the Properties pane, set the Copy to Output Directory value to Copy always.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Set Copy to Output Directory value</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Set Copy to Output Directory value</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The following code sample shows an example service model in a services.xml file:
trans-unit.target: The following code sample shows an example service model in a services.xml file:

trans-unit.source: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?> <serviceModel xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/practices/2011/entlib/autoscaling/serviceModel"> <subscriptions> <subscription name="[subscriptionname]" certificateThumbprint="[managementcertificatethumbprint]" subscriptionId="[subscriptionid]" certificateStoreLocation="CurrentUser" certificateStoreName="My"> <services> <service dnsPrefix="[hostedservicednsprefix]" slot="Staging"> <roles> <role alias="AutoscalingApplicationRole" roleName="[targetrolename]" wadStorageAccountName="targetstorage"/> </roles> </service> </services> <storageAccounts> <storageAccount alias="targetstorage" connectionString="DefaultEndpointsProtocol=https;AccountName=[storageaccountname];AccountKey=[storageaccountkey]"> </storageAccount> </storageAccounts> </subscription> </subscriptions> </serviceModel>
trans-unit.target: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?> <serviceModel xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/practices/2011/entlib/autoscaling/serviceModel"> <subscriptions> <subscription name="[subscriptionname]" certificateThumbprint="[managementcertificatethumbprint]" subscriptionId="[subscriptionid]" certificateStoreLocation="CurrentUser" certificateStoreName="My"> <services> <service dnsPrefix="[hostedservicednsprefix]" slot="Staging"> <roles> <role alias="AutoscalingApplicationRole" roleName="[targetrolename]" wadStorageAccountName="targetstorage"/> </roles> </service> </services> <storageAccounts> <storageAccount alias="targetstorage" connectionString="DefaultEndpointsProtocol=https;AccountName=[storageaccountname];AccountKey=[storageaccountkey]"> </storageAccount> </storageAccounts> </subscription> </subscriptions> </serviceModel>

trans-unit.source: You must replace the values in square brackets with values specific to your environment and target application.
trans-unit.target: You must replace the values in square brackets with values specific to your environment and target application.

trans-unit.source: To find many of these values, you will need to log in to the <linkText>Azure Management Portal</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To find many of these values, you will need to log in to the <linkText>Azure Management Portal</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Sign in to the management portal.
trans-unit.target: Sign in to the management portal.

trans-unit.source: [subscriptionname]: Choose a friendly name to refer to the Azure subscription that contains the application in which you want to use auto-scaling.
trans-unit.target: [subscriptionname]: Choose a friendly name to refer to the Azure subscription that contains the application in which you want to use auto-scaling.

trans-unit.source: [subscriptionid]: The unique ID of the Azure subscription that contains the application in which you want to use auto-scaling.
trans-unit.target: [subscriptionid]: The unique ID of the Azure subscription that contains the application in which you want to use auto-scaling.

trans-unit.source: In the Azure Management Portal, click Cloud Services.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure Management Portal, click Cloud Services.

trans-unit.source: In the list of Cloud Services, click on the service that hosts the application in which you want to use autoscaling.
trans-unit.target: In the list of Cloud Services, click on the service that hosts the application in which you want to use autoscaling.

trans-unit.source: The Quick Glance pane on the right will display the Subscription ID.
trans-unit.target: The Quick Glance pane on the right will display the Subscription ID.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>image</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>image</linkText>

trans-unit.source: [hostedservicednsprefix]: The DNS Prefix of the hosted service in which you want to use auto-scaling.
trans-unit.target: [hostedservicednsprefix]: The DNS Prefix of the hosted service in which you want to use auto-scaling.

trans-unit.source: In the Azure Management Portal, click Cloud Services.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure Management Portal, click Cloud Services.

trans-unit.source: In the list of Cloud Services, locate the service that hosts the application in which you want to use autoscaling.
trans-unit.target: In the list of Cloud Services, locate the service that hosts the application in which you want to use autoscaling.

trans-unit.source: The name of the cloud serviceClick is the DNS Prefix.
trans-unit.target: The name of the cloud serviceClick is the DNS Prefix.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>image</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>image</linkText>

trans-unit.source: [targetrolename]: The name of the role that is the target of your auto-scaling rules.
trans-unit.target: [targetrolename]: The name of the role that is the target of your auto-scaling rules.

trans-unit.source: In the Azure Management Portal, click Cloud Services.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure Management Portal, click Cloud Services.

trans-unit.source: In the list of Cloud Services, click on the service that hosts the application in which you want to use autoscaling, then click Instances.
trans-unit.target: In the list of Cloud Services, click on the service that hosts the application in which you want to use autoscaling, then click Instances.

trans-unit.source: The *Role column displays the name of your target role.
trans-unit.target: The *Role column displays the name of your target role.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>image</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>image</linkText>

trans-unit.source: [storageaccountname] and [storageaccountkey]: The name of the Azure storage account that you are using for your target Azure application.
trans-unit.target: [storageaccountname] and [storageaccountkey]: The name of the Azure storage account that you are using for your target Azure application.

trans-unit.source: In the Azure Management Portal, click Storage.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure Management Portal, click Storage.

trans-unit.source: In the list of Storage Accounts, select the storage account you are using.
trans-unit.target: In the list of Storage Accounts, select the storage account you are using.

trans-unit.source: The Name column will display the Name.
trans-unit.target: The Name column will display the Name.

trans-unit.source: Click the Manage Keys button at the bottom of the screen to get the primary access key.
trans-unit.target: Click the Manage Keys button at the bottom of the screen to get the primary access key.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>image</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>image</linkText>

trans-unit.source: [managementcertificatethumbprint]: The Thumbprint of the Management Certificate that the block will use to secure scaling requests to the target application.
trans-unit.target: [managementcertificatethumbprint]: The Thumbprint of the Management Certificate that the block will use to secure scaling requests to the target application.

trans-unit.source: In the Azure Management Portal, click Settings.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure Management Portal, click Settings.

trans-unit.source: The Thumbprint column will display the Thumbprint.
trans-unit.target: The Thumbprint column will display the Thumbprint.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>image</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>image</linkText>

trans-unit.source: To find out more about the content of the service model file, see <linkText>Storing Your Service Information Data</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To find out more about the content of the service model file, see <linkText>Storing Your Service Information Data</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Typically, you store the autoscaling rules that control the number of role instances in your target application in an XML file.
trans-unit.target: Typically, you store the autoscaling rules that control the number of role instances in your target application in an XML file.

trans-unit.source: You can find a copy of the schema for this XML file in the AutoscalingRules.xsd file in your project.
trans-unit.target: You can find a copy of the schema for this XML file in the AutoscalingRules.xsd file in your project.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, this schema provides Intellisense and validation when you edit the XML file.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, this schema provides Intellisense and validation when you edit the XML file.

trans-unit.source: Create a new XML file named rules.xml in your project.
trans-unit.target: Create a new XML file named rules.xml in your project.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, you must ensure that the rules file is copied to the output folder.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, you must ensure that the rules file is copied to the output folder.

trans-unit.source: To do this:
trans-unit.target: To do this:

trans-unit.source: Right-click on the file and select Properties.
trans-unit.target: Right-click on the file and select Properties.

trans-unit.source: Within the Properties pane, set the Copy to Output Directory value to Copy always.
trans-unit.target: Within the Properties pane, set the Copy to Output Directory value to Copy always.

trans-unit.source: The following code sample shows an example rule set in a rules.xml file:
trans-unit.target: The following code sample shows an example rule set in a rules.xml file:

trans-unit.source: In this example there are three autoscaling rules (one constraint rule and two reactive rules) that operate on a target named AutoscalingApplicationRole that is the alias of a role defined in the service model:
trans-unit.target: In this example there are three autoscaling rules (one constraint rule and two reactive rules) that operate on a target named AutoscalingApplicationRole that is the alias of a role defined in the service model:

trans-unit.source: The constraint rule is always active and sets the minimum number of role instances to two and the maximum number of role instances to six.
trans-unit.target: The constraint rule is always active and sets the minimum number of role instances to two and the maximum number of role instances to six.

trans-unit.source: Both reactive rules use an operand named WebRoleA\_CPU\_Avg\_5m that calculates the average CPU usage over the last five minutes for an Azure role named AutoscalingApplicationRole. This role is defined in the service model.
trans-unit.target: Both reactive rules use an operand named WebRoleA\_CPU\_Avg\_5m that calculates the average CPU usage over the last five minutes for an Azure role named AutoscalingApplicationRole. This role is defined in the service model.

trans-unit.source: The reactive rule named ScaleUpOnHighUtilization increments the instance count of the target role by one if the average CPU utilization over the last five minutes has been greater than or equal to 60%.
trans-unit.target: The reactive rule named ScaleUpOnHighUtilization increments the instance count of the target role by one if the average CPU utilization over the last five minutes has been greater than or equal to 60%.

trans-unit.source: The reactive rule named ScaleDownOnLowUtilization decrements the instance count of the target role by one if the average CPU utilization over the last five minutes has been less than 60%.
trans-unit.target: The reactive rule named ScaleDownOnLowUtilization decrements the instance count of the target role by one if the average CPU utilization over the last five minutes has been less than 60%.

trans-unit.source: After you have defined your service model and autoscaling rules, you must configure the Autoscaling Application Block to use them.
trans-unit.target: After you have defined your service model and autoscaling rules, you must configure the Autoscaling Application Block to use them.

trans-unit.source: This operational configuration information is stored in the application configuration file.
trans-unit.target: This operational configuration information is stored in the application configuration file.

trans-unit.source: By default, the Autoscaling Application Block expects the autoscaling rules and service model to be stored in Azure blobs.
trans-unit.target: By default, the Autoscaling Application Block expects the autoscaling rules and service model to be stored in Azure blobs.

trans-unit.source: In this example, you will configure the block to load them from the local file system.
trans-unit.target: In this example, you will configure the block to load them from the local file system.

trans-unit.source: Right-click on the App.config file in Solution Explorer and then click Edit Configuration File.
trans-unit.target: Right-click on the App.config file in Solution Explorer and then click Edit Configuration File.

trans-unit.source: In the Blocks menu, click Add Autoscaling Settings: image
trans-unit.target: In the Blocks menu, click Add Autoscaling Settings: image

trans-unit.source: Expand the Autoscaling Settings and then click the ellipsis (...) next to the Data Points Store Storage Account, add the Account name and Account key of the Azure storage account where the block will store the data points that it collects (see How To: Define your Service Model if you are unsure about where to find these values), and then click OK:
trans-unit.target: Expand the Autoscaling Settings and then click the ellipsis (...) next to the Data Points Store Storage Account, add the Account name and Account key of the Azure storage account where the block will store the data points that it collects (see How To: Define your Service Model if you are unsure about where to find these values), and then click OK:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>image</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>image</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Expand the Autoscaling Settings section to reveal the Rules Store and Service Information Store sections.
trans-unit.target: Expand the Autoscaling Settings section to reveal the Rules Store and Service Information Store sections.

trans-unit.source: By default, they are configured to use Azure blob storage: <linkText>image</linkText>
trans-unit.target: By default, they are configured to use Azure blob storage: <linkText>image</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click the plus sign (+) next to Rules Store, point to Set Rules Store, then click Use Local File Rules Store, and then click Yes.
trans-unit.target: Click the plus sign (+) next to Rules Store, point to Set Rules Store, then click Use Local File Rules Store, and then click Yes.

trans-unit.source: In the File Name box, type rules.xml.
trans-unit.target: In the File Name box, type rules.xml.

trans-unit.source: This is the name of the file that contains your autoscaling rules: <linkText>image</linkText>
trans-unit.target: This is the name of the file that contains your autoscaling rules: <linkText>image</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click the plus sign (+) next to Service Information Store, point to Set Service Information Store, then click Use Local File Service Information Store, and then click Yes.
trans-unit.target: Click the plus sign (+) next to Service Information Store, point to Set Service Information Store, then click Use Local File Service Information Store, and then click Yes.

trans-unit.source: In the File Name box, type services.xml.
trans-unit.target: In the File Name box, type services.xml.

trans-unit.source: This is the name of the file that contains your autoscaling rules: <linkText>image</linkText>
trans-unit.target: This is the name of the file that contains your autoscaling rules: <linkText>image</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Enterprise Library Configuration window, on the File menu, click Save to save your configuration changes.
trans-unit.target: In the Enterprise Library Configuration window, on the File menu, click Save to save your configuration changes.

trans-unit.source: Then in the Enterprise Library Configuration window, on the File menu, click Exit.
trans-unit.target: Then in the Enterprise Library Configuration window, on the File menu, click Exit.

trans-unit.source: To get detailed information about the actions that the Autoscaling Application Block is performing you need to capture the log messages that it writes.
trans-unit.target: To get detailed information about the actions that the Autoscaling Application Block is performing you need to capture the log messages that it writes.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you are hosting the block in a console application, you can view the log messages in the Output window in Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: For example, if you are hosting the block in a console application, you can view the log messages in the Output window in Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: The following section shows you how to configure this behavior.
trans-unit.target: The following section shows you how to configure this behavior.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, double-click on the App.config file in Solution Explorer to open it in the editor.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, double-click on the App.config file in Solution Explorer to open it in the editor.

trans-unit.source: Then add the system.diagnostics section as shown in the following sample:
trans-unit.target: Then add the system.diagnostics section as shown in the following sample:

trans-unit.source: Save your changes.
trans-unit.target: Save your changes.

trans-unit.source: You can now run your Autoscaling Application Block host console application and observe how the autoscaling rules work with your target Azure application.
trans-unit.target: You can now run your Autoscaling Application Block host console application and observe how the autoscaling rules work with your target Azure application.

trans-unit.source: When you run the host console application, you should see messages similar to the following in the Output window in Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: When you run the host console application, you should see messages similar to the following in the Output window in Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: These log messages help you to understand the behavior of the block.
trans-unit.target: These log messages help you to understand the behavior of the block.

trans-unit.source: For example, they indicate which rules are being matched by the block and what actions the block is taking.
trans-unit.target: For example, they indicate which rules are being matched by the block and what actions the block is taking.
